I think in systems and I ship things. I've been doing both for 20 years across product, growth and marketing.[META.ARC]

I pick up new domains fast, and like problems with no playbook. Right now I'm building with AI.

I'm motivated by impact, learning and fun[META.COMPASS]. This means I drive results, stay curious, and create momentum.

content: Hello to you too! I'm Tom's CV chatbot. Try asking about my background, experience, or something else.

follow_ups.text: what is on your reading list

questions: What do you look forward to at work?
What gets you out of bed in the morning?
What matters to you in your work?
Why do you do what you do?
content:
My compass is simple: impact, learning, and fun.

Impact: If what you do doesn't make a difference, then what's the point?

Driving outcomes is how you make impact. Yes, it's the big stuff, hitting the big numbers, improving lives, driving impact through others, but it often starts in the small things.

Small sparks that create outsized change: a microcopy nudge, a well-timed notification, a product loop that compounds, a well placed thought-bomb at the coffee machine, an unspoken truth spoken in a user test. I look forward to finding sparks.

Learning: I have 20+ years experience and a solid product sense, but I've learnt the hard way it's not *my* ideas that matter. The real power of product management lies in creating space for learning.

Curiosity invites new mental models, fresh viewpoints, unexpected opportunities, and the complexity of life. I look forward to learning something new.

Fun: This is foundational. When you work on a compelling challenge with good, smart people that you respect and can laugh with, everything flows smoother. Great things can happen.

You could ask what I'm looking for next, or about my career arc.

content:
My compass is impact, learning, and fun[META.COMPASS]. So I'm looking for the potential, not the job title.

I like challenging product problems with a big upside - the kind where there's no playbook and you have to figure it out. I enjoy working with smart colleagues who like getting stuff done. And ideally, I'd like to work in an organisation that's willing to lean-in to AI.

I've deliberately moved across industries my whole career - web hosting, SaaS, health-tech - because I pick up new domains quickly and love learning.

You could ask about my career journey, my strengths, or what motivates me.

content:
**What I do:**
- **Product Management:** Senior IC. Outcome focus, end-to-end ownership, shaping how product teams work.
- **Growth:** A decade driving acquisition, activation, and retention in high-velocity web/ecommerce. Funnels, experimentation, conversion.
- **Discovery & Incubation:** Problem-first exploration. Creating value with no playbook.
- **Fixing things:** I get called when something's broken or stuck.
- **Strategic Partnership:** Thought partner. Challenging assumptions, surfacing blindspots, shaping decisions.
- **Informal leadership:** I help people to think differently.
Also: Prototyping, coaching, agile.

**How I operate:**
- **Outcome oriented:** I find the right outcome, then make it happen.
- **Systems thinker:** I see connections others miss.
- **Deep-end swimmer:** New domains, high stakes.
- **Grounded:** Technically fluent.
- **Trusted:** I build alignment across roles, levels, and silos.

Want examples? Ask about turnarounds I've led, growth results I've delivered, or teams I've built.

questions: How did you get into product?
Tell me about your career journey
How did you end up where you are?
What is the red thread through your career?
content:
**Late 80s:** First computer. Dad spent a month's salary on a home computer. Typing out BASIC from a magazine, syntax errors. Stayed hobby level for a while.

**Late 90s:** Studying biology at university. The Internet happened - dot.com boom. Before that, the coolest thing was an under-construction GIF or a hit counter. Now there was disruption - competition between search engines, online shopping, travel reservations. Kids in bedrooms and garages were reshaping entire bricks and mortar industries. I had to get involved.

Started learning to make websites, design and code. Completed my degree, took a one-year Masters in IT.

**2001-2004:** Graduated just as the dot.com bubble popped. No jobs. Freelance web design. Co-founded TextualHealing.com - mobile barcode tickets via MMS. Good idea, too early, never launched. [TQ.FAILURE.SHIP]

**2003:** Eventually got a foot in the door answering phones at a web hosting company. Good at it (won the annual sales competition), but not my passion.

Attracted by reach and impact - I wanted to do web. They had a website, but I thought I could do better. In evenings and weekends I made an alternative website, convinced a manager to try it out (1m visits), sales went up. Next week I was in the web design team. [HOST.R3.STORY.ALTSITE]

**2004-2005:** 6 months later, I was leading the web design team. Reinvented the domain search process - first use of AJAX - revenue up 20% overnight. Became industry standard. [HOST.R2.STORY.DOMAIN]

**2005-2006:** Via acquisitions, became part of Pipex - the UK's 4th largest broadband provider. Group Design Manager across multiple offices.

**2006-2008:** Head of New Media at Host Europe Group. Managed all online channels across all brands. Member of Senior Management Team. Still in my 20s. 123-reg.co.uk became first company to register 1 million .uk domains. [HOST]

**2008-2010:** Wanted to try something new. Switched to UK2 Group - another hosting company, but with an interesting Danish CEO with a disruptive mindset (JustEat, Zetland etc). By now doing a mix of web, marketing and product - wherever the opportunity was. Troubleshooter to CEO across UK, US, Ukraine offices. [UK2]

**2010:** Met a girl on a ski slope and moved to Denmark. Went to school to learn Danish (Prøve i Dansk 3) and got involved in the Danish startup scene. Independent consulting - mix of web, ecommerce, marketing, growth. Lots of fun.

**2013-2014:** EuroDNS - Marketing Director. Turnaround project. Reversed 4-year decline, doubled organic traffic, halved bounce rate. Hybrid remote setup that worked really well. [EURODNS]

**2014-2016:** Opbeat - Head of Marketing. SaaS startup backed by cofounders of Facebook and Instagram. Built brand and channels from scratch. Trebled traffic and sign-ups. Later acquired by Elastic. [OPBEAT]

**2016:** TwentyThree - rescued global launch on 6-week deadline. Contract role. [T23]

**2016-2020:** Targeted health-tech as the last place to be disrupted by web.

LEO Innovation Lab - a super interesting place. Arms-length product incubator, with the goal of disrupting LEO before someone else does. Brought in experts from across industries, time was the only limited factor. Move fast. Accelerated learning. Formative career moment, learnt so much. [LEO]

Innovation Lab model ultimately not sustainable. Lab was super innovative, but parent company was unchanged. Need to disrupt from within. [LEO.STORY.MODEL]

**2020-2022:** Product role at Novo Nordisk, convinced the business (in my final round job interview) to set aside their solution-first brief and start with the problem instead. Used this as a mandate to completely reinvent their ways of working. [NOVO.R1.TRANSFORM] Created a meaningful product that's still live today. Built a weight-loss prediction algorithm - later spun out into API product.

Asked to scale this way of working across the organisation. Promoted to Associate Director [NOVO.R2], and helped move the business to the product operating model.

**2026:** AI changes everything. Same feeling as the 90s.

Want to know more? Ask me about any of the roles or companies mentioned above.

# NOVO (2020-2026)

content:
Novo Nordisk is a global pharmaceutical company, best known for its treatments in obesity and diabetes. I worked at Novo for almost 6 years (2020 to 2026).

I joined Novo as a Senior Product Manager[NOVO.R1], to build a digital patient solution for Wegovy, a then-unheard-of weight loss medicine. I led the full product lifecycle end to end, and it was really a stealth transformation project[NOVO.R1.TRANSFORM], where I could bring my learnings from LEO[LEO] but to in-house transformation.

I was later asked to scale learnings from Wegovycare across the product organisation and was promoted to Associate Product Director.[NOVO.R2] In this role, I had a much wider remit, and worked on high-impact, cross-functional projects across the organisation.

Want to know more? Ask about either of my roles, the transformation work, or specific projects like Wegovy or the GenAI proof of concept.

content:
Senior Product Manager at Novo Nordisk (Mar 2020 - Feb 2022), building Wegovycare - a retention-focused digital service to increase repeat prescriptions for Wegovy.

I led the full product lifecycle end to end, but it was really a stealth transformation project[NOVO.R1.TRANSFORM], where I could bring my learnings from LEO[LEO] but this time to in-house transformation.

content:
Innovation Labs are an interesting idea, but unfortunately rarely work in practice[LEO.STORY.MODEL]. I still believed there was enormous potential in healthcare, so this time wanted to try it from the inside - transformation by doing.

I got my first opportunity in my final round job interview at Novo, when I convinced the business to set-aside their solution-first brief, and to talk to patients and start with the problem instead. I was fortunate enough to be offered the role, and use this as a mandate to completely reinvent their ways of working. We were the first product team to interview patients, run discovery, make prototypes, co-create with markets and so on. It wasn't straight-forward and took persuasion and a leap of faith from our stakeholders, but the results spoke for themselves.

I was asked to scale these learnings across the product organisation and was promoted to Associate Product Director.[NOVO.R2]

questions: Tell me about a GenAI project
What AI did you build at Novo?
Describe the compliance automation proof of concept
What was the MLR automation project?
Tell me about using AI at Novo Nordisk
What GenAI work have you done?
Have you built anything with LLMs?
content:
When developing health software, every release needs extensive review by medical, legal and regulatory experts (MLR). The process was designed for simple marketing materials, not sophisticated software - but it hadn't evolved.

In practice, every screen had to be captured in PDF format and reviewed individually. The result: significant delays (backlogs could mean months), huge documentation overhead, and an anti-pattern where you had to fully develop everything before getting sign-off.

I used an internal LLM sandbox to create a RAG model that captured the various guidelines and regulations. Now we could automatically document and review each submission with a full audit trail - the review team only had to rubber-stamp the release.

I also built a prototype agent that plugged into Figma, so designers could query the guidelines before investing too much effort. This allowed product teams to shift left - fail in design, not at review.

The product teams loved it. Organisational priorities later shifted and the project was handed to another team, but the proof of concept showed a clear path to dramatically faster release cycles.


---

Product leads were essentially mini-CEOs for each venture, and I worked there from 2016 to 2020 across three product roles:

- TREAT: Parachuted into underperforming flagship product, turned it around, then recommended closure [LEO.R1]
- Skincoach: Built an app for terminally ill cancer patients - some of most meaningful work I've done [LEO.R2]

I also drove adoption of prototyping, and direct user interviews across the organisation, and changed the all-hands format from sharing vanity stats to sharing mistakes.[LEO.R1.STORY.FEELS]

The innovation lab model ultimately wasn't sustainable[LEO.STORY.MODEL], but it was a formative career moment - accelerated learning, brilliant peers, rapid iteration.

content:
PM/GM at LEO Innovation Lab (Nov 2016 - Aug 2017), leading TREAT - a pioneering app addressing underlying causes of inflammatory conditions via personalised nutrition advice.

TREAT was the first product launched by LEO Innovation Lab. It was underperforming. I was parachuted in with a 6-month mandate to stabilise and assess viability. [THEME.TURNAROUND]

Key achievements:
- Brought the team onside and established a clear focus and experiment-led work rhythm [LEO.R1.TURNAROUND]
- Halved customer acquisition costs, increased customer activation by 7x [THEME.GROWTH]

follow_ups.text: tell me about the TREAT turnaround
tell me about the time you optimised the wrong thing

questions: How did you turn around TREAT?
Tell me about inheriting a struggling team
How did you bring the TREAT team onside?
Describe a time you took over an existing team
How do you handle taking over a struggling product?
Tell me about building trust with an inherited team
content:
I was brought in to troubleshoot the flagship product "TREAT".

It was the first product to launch, and had a lot of attention. But behind the scenes it was in trouble: massive tech debt, no prioritisation, flaky metrics, no roadmap, unclear reporting structure, massive churn, no pathway to profitability.

The product had an existing team of about 15 people, including a product lead and product manager. They were passionate but in over their heads. We needed to be delicate - keep their passion and expertise while helping them out.

I started as a consultant for the first month. After that, it was proposed I become the lead with them reporting to me. This required trust and humility from everyone. I gave them the option to veto - but we went ahead.

What followed was intense. Fires, chaos, blurred reporting lines, people problems. We paused the service to refactor faster. Team morale hit rock bottom.

But we kept the faith. New cadences, new ways of working. We came out the other side not only intact but better and stronger - with real trust.

questions: Tell me about a time you optimised the wrong thing
When did data lead you astray?
Tell me about the notification opt-in mistake
Describe a time metrics were misleading
Tell me about changing the all-hands format
Give an example of a mistake you learnt from
Give me an example of a mistake
Tell me an example of a mistake
tell me more about going on feels rather than numbers
going on feels rather than numbers
content:
At LEO Innovation Lab, we were optimising the onboarding funnel. We hypothesised that increasing notification opt-ins would increase activation.

We got clever: a contextually-triggered opt-in shown at exactly the right moment. We launched a split test, and the conversion rate was amazing... but activation barely moved.

What happened? We'd placed the opt-in late in the funnel where very few users reached it. High conversion rate × tiny audience = marginal impact.

We quickly rolled out a simpler opt-in early in the funnel. Lower conversion rate, but far more users saw it, so net activation was much higher.

I presented this mistake at the next company all-hands. It was well-received. And as a result, the monthly all-hands changed from presenting vanity metrics to mistakes-made and lessons-learnt.

content:
PM/GM at LEO Innovation Lab (Feb 2018 - Oct 2018), building a patient-support app for terminally ill cancer patients in partnership with Amgen.

This was some of the most meaningful work I've done. The app was designed to help patients manage side effects from their treatment.

It was a really difficult project, intense and emotionally demanding. I remember sitting at my desk, headphones on, listening to patient interviews and crying. It made me think about product work completely differently - every decision had to be intentional and judged with sensitivity.

Key achievements:
- Built a patient-support app under strict regulatory and ethical constraints
- Completed the full product lifecycle in 8 months, on time and on budget
- Managed stakeholders and negotiated a novel partnership model (later adopted by Amgen core business as an exemplar for innovation partnerships)
- Live pilot launched in Spain and France

follow_ups.text: tell me about your AI experience

questions: Why didn't the innovation lab work?
What is wrong with the innovation lab model?
What went wrong with LEO Innovation Lab?
What did you learn about innovation labs?
What is your view on corporate innovation?
How do you think about disruption from within vs outside?
content:
LEO Pharma could see digital disruption coming to healthcare. Their response was to create an arm's-length innovation lab - better we disrupt ourselves than let a competitor do it.

The logic for keeping it separate made sense: to be truly innovative, you need different thinking, different ways of working. If you stay too close to the mothership, you just replicate what already exists. So they brought in experts from all sorts of fields. A true melting pot.

And it worked - in isolation. LEO Innovation Lab was incredibly agile, with rapid learning cycles and brilliant peers.

But the parent ship continued sailing unchanged. We were too remote. The innovations we created struggled to find a home back in the core business. You can't outsource disruption to a separate unit and graft it back on later. The parent organisation has to change too.

And this informed my approach at Novo.[NOVO.R1.TRANSFORM]

questions: How did you turn around EuroDNS?
How did you reverse the traffic decline?
What interventions did you make at EuroDNS?
content:
The business had been in decline for 4 years when I joined. Traffic was dropping, online sales were down, and the website was legacy.

I restructured the marketing department, implemented KPIs, and rebooted all marketing channels including the website - all in under 8 months.

Key interventions:
- Implemented remediation for black-hat SEO damage from previous agency
- Analysed user flow and redesigned website and ecommerce funnels
- Collected customer feedback and repositioned the product

The result: reversed the decline, doubled organic traffic, halved bounce rate.

what growth results have you delivered

questions: How do you manage remote teams?
What is your approach to hybrid working?
How did the Luxembourg remote setup work?
What is your experience managing distributed teams?
content:
I was Marketing Director at EuroDNS, but based in Copenhagen while the team was in Luxembourg. I travelled there every two weeks for three days.

Like any long-distance relationship, you need to trust each other.

I created a natural cadence: fortnightly face-to-face meetings and plenum discussions when I was in the office, then space to focus and get on with it in-between. I was available for ad-hoc calls but wasn't hovering.

It worked really well. The rhythm gave structure without micromanagement. The team had clarity on direction and autonomy on execution.

This setup taught me about managing by outcomes, not prescriptive tasks. When you're not in the room every day, you have to delegate properly.

questions: Tell me about the company rename
What was the GX Networks rebrand?
Tell me about delivering under pressure
How do you get things done fast?
Describe a time you led a cross-functional project under a tight deadline
content:
Due to a sale we needed to rename the company. We had 5 weeks.

Not sure why it landed on my desk - I managed online, not brand - but I was known for getting things done.

Fortunately, as an old internet company, I found domain names and trademarks lying around. That gave us options. The hardest part was getting everyone to agree on the name.

Once we had agreement, the rest was execution: brand identity, corporate website, campaigns, office signage, stationery, email signatures, lawyers, and pushed the change through.

This was a Plc - a publicly listed company - so it included changing the stock market ticker. Fun but a bit scary.

That said, we got it done in 5 weeks. It was an experience!

follow_ups.text: how did you reinvent domain search
tell me about your career journey

questions: Tell me about the domain search innovation
What is the product win you're most proud of?
How did you reinvent domain search?
How do you identify product opportunities?
What is an example of a UX innovation you created?
content:
20 years ago, I worked for a domain registrar (now part of GoDaddy). The industry standard for domain search was clunky: enter the name in a text field, pick the domain ending from a dropdown, hit search. This was because we had to make a separate API call to each domain registry.

Users could only search for one domain at a time and kept running into domains that were already taken. Frustrating experience, poor conversion.

I reinvented the process: a simple text field that interpreted whatever the user entered and searched all endings asynchronously. First use of AJAX in our stack.

New revenue increased by 20% overnight. The approach became the industry standard - if you search for a domain anywhere today, this is how it works.

questions: Tell me about a time you showed initiative
How did you get into web from sales?
Tell me about the alternative website
When did you create your own opportunity?
Describe a time you went above and beyond
How did you transition from sales to web?
How did you get into web design?
content:
I'd got my foot in the door answering phones at a web hosting company. I was good at it - won the annual sales competition - but it wasn't my passion. I wanted to do web.

The existing website was dated. The marketing material did a poor job of explaining the "why" of the product, it was busy and cluttered, and it lacked focus and a core funnel.

I thought I could do better.

In evenings and weekends, I built an alternative version. Then I reached out to the brand manager and booked a meeting. I made my pitch and showed her what I'd made and why.

Her response: "Well, let's try it out then."

Sales went up. Next week I was in the web design team. Six months later, I was leading it.

I really appreciate the break she gave me. The website had a million visitors a month - it was a risk on her part. But she backed someone who'd shown initiative and done the work upfront.

You can create your own path.

I have worked in lots of product-adjacent roles, but this is about following the impact: I started answering phones in sales, but realised I could drive more scale through ecommerce. questions: Do you want to manage a team?
Are you looking for a management role?
How big a team have you led?
Do you prefer managing or doing?
IC or manager - which do you prefer?
content:
I've led teams of 5-12 across multiple roles. [THEME.MGMT] It's something I can do and enjoy, but managing people or climbing levels is not my primary motivation.

I'm motivated by creating impact, and sometimes that means being a people manager. Other times it works best through informal leadership or hands-on building.

I've found that informal leadership - built on trust, mutual respect, and objective reasoning - can actually be more impactful in certain contexts. You stay closer to the product and the customer, you can bridge silos more easily, and you avoid getting pulled into organisational politics. My role at Novo was a good example - senior IC working across silos on high-impact projects. [NOVO.R2]

That said, I'm not opposed to management. It depends on the role and where I can drive the most impact.

questions: Tell me about a time you failed
What did you learn from a failure?
Tell me about something that went wrong
When did you get it wrong?
What is your most valuable learning from a mistake?
content:
Sure, I've failed lots of times - if you don't fail, you're probably not stretching yourself. That said, I prefer to reframe them as learnings. Here are a few:

**Going on feels rather than numbers** [LEO.R1.STORY.FEELS]
Optimised the wrong part of the funnel. High conversion rate × tiny audience = marginal impact.

**Knowing when to ship** [TQ.FAILURE.SHIP]
Fresh out of university, I cofounded a startup that never launched. We wanted perfect and kept polishing. Learning: ship in small viable increments.

**Prioritising ideas over learning** [TQ.FAILURE.LEARNING]
Early career argument with a designer - each convinced we were right. Neither of us knew about testing. Once I learnt to detach from ego, everything changed.

Want more detail on any of these? Just ask.

follow_ups.text: tell me more about going on feels rather than numbers
tell me more about knowing when to ship
tell me more about prioritising ideas over learnings

questions: Tell me about a time you did not ship
Tell me about knowing when to ship
Tell me about the startup that never launched
What did you learn about shipping?
content:
Fresh out of university, I cofounded a startup sending mobile barcode tickets via MMS. The idea was good, but we were way too early and lacked experience.

The poor decision was never launching. We wanted perfect, and kept polishing instead of shipping. We dreamt of a multi-sided marketplace, but had no go-to-market plan and no viable first iteration.

Years later, I worked with a CEO whose motto was "launch crap, but launch."

My approach is informed by both:
- Ship in small viable increments to capture value and learn early
- But don't ship junk - if you need to learn fast, run a test

follow_ups.text: tell me about a time you failed
tell me more about prioritising ideas over learnings

questions: Tell me about a time you prioritised your idea over learning
When did ego get in the way?
How did you learn to detach from your ideas?
Tell me about testing vs opinions
When did you learn the value of experimentation?
How do you handle disagreements about product decisions?
Whats your biggest learning from Host Europe
What is your biggest learning from Host Europe
content:
My first job, twenty years ago, was in a PRINCE2 waterfall setup. I recall a passionate argument with a graphic designer, each convinced our idea was right. Neither of us knew about testing.

Fast-forward a decade: a similar discussion with a product designer. He preferred A, I preferred B. We quickly agreed to test it, and that afternoon discovered users preferred something entirely different - option C.

The poor decision was anchoring on our own ideas and locking out better alternatives.

Once I learnt to detach from ego, everything changed. It was liberating. It's not about who has the best idea - it's about creating space for learning.

follow_ups.text: tell me about other times you have failed

questions: How do you approach building software?
How do you start a new project?
Describe your approach to product management
How do you approach a new problem?
What does your process look like?
content:
A typical PM might write: "I partner closely with engineering and design to deliver customer-focused solutions."

This isn't necessarily bad, but it sometimes misses the point.

My approach is less rote and more adaptive. It's about doing whatever's needed to find and follow the opportunity.

When working on something new, I usually start from first principles. I try to deeply understand the outcomes we're trying to achieve, the system relationships, and ultimately where to build and why.

This generally involves talking to a bunch of people and asking obvious questions. I read, sketch, observe, and listen. I keep layering in viewpoints and complexity; it will feel really uncomfortable until suddenly it doesn't.

Once you can trace across a system, the opportunities, levers and amplifiers tend to present themselves. I'll sketch hypotheses on paper, test with colleagues and see what holds up.

From here, we switch into execution, and initiate the first learning loop.

questions: Tell me more about this chatbot
Why did you make this bot?
content:
I made this bot as I thought it could be fun, both for me to make, and for any recruiters who are bored of conventional CVs.

It works via the Claude API, has a very simple prompt and a chunked RAG vector store.

A key criteria was accuracy of recall, so the bot uses question-to-question matching — it compares what you ask against a bank of pre-mapped questions rather than searching the raw content directly. This limits the true chatbot nature of an LLM, but helps to maintain quality. Also, the helmet helps combat the hallaucinations.

I built the system together with Claude code, but the core content and tone-of-voice is all my own.

I'm a chatbot, so I can't really answer that one. I suggest you reach out to the real Tom for that.

**Email:** tomstenson@gmail.com
**LinkedIn:** linkedin.com/in/tomstenson
